content.rendered:
In this book, companion to his bestselling Mythos, Stephen Fry brilliantly retells dramatic, funny, tragic and timeless greek tales.

Since the first book (Mythos) was more about Olympian gods and their doings, Heroes is the story of what we mortals are truly capable of – at our worst and our very best.

excerpt.rendered: Since the first book (Mythos) was more about Olympian gods and their doings, Heroes is the story of what we mortals are truly capable of – at our worst and our very best.

acf.author: Stephen Fry
acf.opinion:
This is a better book than the first part of Stephen Fry’s series of classic greek stories. Most likely this is because this one has the most legendary characters like Hercules and Oedipus etc.

These are classic stories told with original content, but with modern day language.
acf.who: People who are interested in classic stories and European cultural history.

content.rendered: This has always been one of my favourite novels and I have read it probably ten times, but previously translated in Finnish, now first time in original language (English). Classic story about Jim Hawkins, Long John Silver and buried treasure of Captain Flint is most likely best known pirate story in history of literature.

excerpt.rendered: This has always been one of my favourite novels and I have read it probably ten times. Classic story about Jim Hawkins, Long John Silver and buried treasure of Captain Flint is most likely best known pirate story in history of literature.

acf.author: Robert Louis Stevenson
acf.opinion: Simply a great book. Some parts of the story twists are obvious, but some for the first time reader (I think) might be surprising. Characters are interesting and feel like a realistic human beens. Style of a language story is written is showing some serious mastery of words.
acf.who: Anyone who even remotely like novels.

title.rendered: The Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother

content.rendered:
An awe-inspiring, often hilarious, and unerringly honest story of one mother’s exercise in extreme parenting, revealing the rewards-and the costs-of raising her children the Chinese way.

All decent parents want to do what’s best for their children. What Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother reveals is that the Chinese just have a totally different idea of how to do that. Western parents try to respect their children’s individuality, encouraging them to pursue their true passions and providing a nurturing environment. The Chinese believe that the best way to protect your children is by preparing them for the future and arming them with skills, strong work habits, and inner confidence. Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother chronicles Chua’s iron-willed decision to raise her daughters, Sophia and Lulu, her way-the Chinese way-and the remarkable results her choice inspires.

excerpt.rendered: Interesting personal story with a great sense of intellectual humour and great insights on cultural differences.

acf.author: Amy Chua
acf.opinion: Interesting personal story with a great sense of intellectual humour and great insights on cultural differences.
acf.who: People interested in other cultures and also for any parent.

content.rendered:
Among the towering red cliffs of Petra, like some monstrous swollen Buddha, sits the corpse of Mrs. Boynton. A tiny puncture mark on her wrist is the only sign of the fatal injection that killed her.

With only twenty-four hours available to solve the mystery, Hercule Poirot recalled a chance remark he’d overheard back in Jerusalem: “You see, don’t you, that she’s got to be killed?” Mrs. Boynton was, indeed, the most detestable woman he’d ever met. . . .

excerpt.rendered: This is a classic style Hercule Poirot novel and quite good one.

acf.author: Agatha Christie
acf.opinion: This is a classic style Poirot novel and quite good one.
acf.who: People who like traditional crime mysteries.

content.rendered: The Knights Templar were the wealthiest, most powerful – and most secretive – of the military orders that flourished in the crusading era. Their story – encompassing as it does the greatest international conflict of the Middle Ages, a network of international finance, a swift rise in wealth and influence followed by a bloody and humiliating fall – has left a comet’s tail of mystery that continues to fascinate and inspire historians, novelists and conspiracy theorists.

excerpt.rendered: This is an objective and fact based history of Templars without pop-culture additions or any romanticising. It also gives some insights of medieval political life in general.

acf.author: Dan Jones
acf.opinion: This is an objective and fact based history of Templars without pop-culture additions or any romanticising. It also gives some insights of medieval political life in general.
acf.who: People interested in Templar history or medieval history in general.

content.rendered: How will Artificial Intelligence affect crime, war, justice, jobs, society and our very sense of being human? The rise of AI has the potential to transform our future more than any other technology—and there’s nobody better qualified or situated to explore that future than Max Tegmark, an MIT professor who’s helped mainstream research on how to keep AI beneficial.

excerpt.rendered: This is the most well informed and neutral book about future of AI I have read, by an author who’s has great authority in this field.

acf.author: Max Tegmark
acf.opinion: This non-fiction book starts with (very entertaining) fictional short story about birth of AI utopia. Then book goes through possible effects of AI in different areas of life. It sets multiple scenarios of what could happen and what is realistic. This is the most well informed and neutral book about future of AI I have read, by an author who’s has great authority in this field.
acf.who: People who are interested in Artificial Intelligence and how it can effect our society.

content.rendered:
Most startups fail. But many of those failures are preventable.  The Lean Startup is a new approach being adopted across the globe, changing the way companies are built and new products are launched.

Eric Ries defines a startup as an organization dedicated to creating something new under conditions of extreme uncertainty. This is just as true for one person in a garage or a group of seasoned professionals in a Fortune 500 boardroom. What they have in common is a mission to penetrate that fog of uncertainty to discover a successful path to a sustainable business.

excerpt.rendered: Most startups fail. But many of those failures are preventable.  The Lean Startup is a new approach being adopted across the globe, changing the way companies are built and new products are launched.

acf.author: Eric Ries
acf.opinion: This is a essential book for all startup founders, but also for all business leaders who wan’t to keep up with the changing world.
acf.who: Startup founders and business leaders.

content.rendered: Yuval Noah Harari returns in August 2018 with a new book, 21 Lessons for the 21st Century. In bringing his focus to the here and now, Harari will help us to grapple with a world that is increasingly hard to comprehend, encouraging us to focus our minds on the essential questions we should be asking ourselves today. Employing his trademark entertaining and lucid style, Harari will examine some of the world’s most urgent issues, including terrorism, fake news and immigration, as well as turning to more individual concerns, from resilience and humility to meditation.

excerpt.rendered: Yuval Noah Harari returns in August 2018 with a new book, 21 Lessons for the 21st Century. In bringing his focus to the here and now

acf.author: Yuval Noah Harari
acf.opinion: Like all the previous Harari’s books this one is excellent. Book focuses to analyze world situation right now and how we end up there. Also it speculates where it might lead to in very philosophical way.
acf.who: People interested in world situation, politics, philosophy or history.

content.rendered:
Uber. Airbnb. Amazon. Apple. PayPal. All of these companies disrupted their markets when they launched. Today they are industry leaders. What’s the secret to their success?

These cutting-edge businesses are built on platforms: two-sided markets that are revolutionizing the way we do business. Written by three of the most sought-after experts on platform businesses, Platform Revolution is the first authoritative, fact-based book on platform models. Whether platforms are connecting sellers and buyers, hosts and visitors, or drivers with people who need a ride, Geoffrey G. Parker, Marshall W. Van Alstyne, and Sangeet Paul Choudary reveal the what, how, and why of this revolution and provide the first “owner’s manual” for creating a successful platform business.

excerpt.rendered: This books is a good business book introducing reader to Platform based business model and how it works.

acf.author: Geoffrey G. Parker, Marshall W. Van Alstyne , Sangeet Paul Choudary
acf.opinion: This books is a good business book introducing reader to Platform based business model and it works.
acf.who: Anyone interested in business books.

content.rendered: This is the intimate story of twenty tsars and tsarinas of Russia, some touched by genius, some by madness, but all inspired by holy autocracy and imperial ambition. Simon Sebag Montefiore’s gripping chronicle reveals their secret world of unlimited power and ruthless empire-building, overshadowed by palace conspiracy, family rivalries, sexual decadence, and wild extravagance.

excerpt.rendered: This was a good basic view of Romanov family and their 300 year reign of Russia. It really focuses on Romanov family and reader doesn’t get really good sense of historical context where events takes place.

acf.author: Simon Sebag Montefiore
acf.opinion: This was a good basic view of Romanov family and their 300 year reign of Russia. It really focuses on Romanov dynasty and reader doesn’t get really good sense of historical context where events takes place. For example giving a year when something was happening would have made it lot more clearer to follow.
acf.who: People interested in Russian history

content.rendered: Seven lectures by the brilliant theoretical physicist have been compiled into this book to try to explain to the common man, the complex problems of mathematics and the question that has been gripped everyone all for centuries, the theory of existence.

excerpt.rendered: Seven lectures by the brilliant theoretical physicist have been compiled into this book to try to explain to the common man, the complex problems of mathematics and the question that has been gripped everyone all for centuries, the theory of existence.

acf.author: Stephen Hawking
acf.opinion: This was really similar to authors more famous book The Brief History of Time. This book is bit deeper than some other popular science books and personally I can’t say I understood everything said in this book, but I managed to catch some enlightening information about our universe. This book is a good next step after you first read for example Astrophysics for People in a Hurry by Neil De Grasse Tyson.
acf.who: Anyone interested in physics and how our universe works.

title.rendered: Origin Story: A Big History of everything

content.rendered:
Most historians study the smallest slivers of time, emphasizing specific dates, individuals, and documents. But what would it look like to study the whole of history, from the big bang through the present day — and even into the remote future? That is what this book is all about.

In Origin Story, Christian takes readers on a wild ride through the entire 13.8 billion years we’ve come to know as “history.” By focusing on defining events (thresholds), major trends, and profound questions about our origins, Christian exposes the hidden threads that tie everything together — from the creation of the planet to the advent of agriculture, nuclear war, and beyond.

excerpt.rendered: In Origin Story, Christian takes readers on a wild ride through the entire 13.8 billion years we’ve come to know as “history.” By focusing on defining events (thresholds), major trends, and profound questions about our origins, Christian exposes the hidden threads that tie everything together.

acf.author: David Christian
acf.opinion: This book really makes you think about big picture. It’s refreshing take on history and specially core concepts of civilization.
acf.who: For people who are interested to understand better what is civilization all about.

content.rendered:
Christmas Eve, and the Lee family’s reunion is shattered by a deafening crash of furniture and a high-pitched wailing scream. Upstairs, the tyrannical Simeon Lee lies dead in a pool of blood, his throat slashed.

When Hercule Poirot offers to assist, he finds an atmosphere not of mourning but of mutual suspicion. It seems everyone had their own reason to hate the old man

excerpt.rendered: Christmas Eve, and the Lee family’s reunion is shattered by a deafening crash of furniture and a high-pitched wailing scream. Upstairs, the tyrannical Simeon Lee lies dead in a pool of blood, his throat slashed.

acf.author: Agatha Christie
acf.opinion: This one of the best Poirot novels by Agatha Christie. It is a classical murder in a English mansion mystery with interesting characters and surprising ending.
acf.who: Anyone who likes Agatha Christies novels.

content.rendered: The Queen of Mystery has come to Harper Collins! Agatha Christie, the acknowledged mistress of suspense—creator of indomitable sleuth Miss Marple, meticulous Belgian detective Hercule Poirot, and so many other unforgettable characters—brings her entire oeuvre of ingenious whodunits, locked room mysteries, and perplexing puzzles to Harper Paperbacks…including Murder on the Orient Express, the most famous Hercule Poirot mystery, which has the brilliant detective hunting for a killer aboard one of the world’s most luxurious passenger trains.

excerpt.rendered: Since there is a new movie made from this book, I decided to read it again. This classic still works. This is one of the best detective novels ever.

acf.author: Agatha Christie
acf.opinion:
Since there is a new movie made from this book, I decided to read it again. This classic still works. This is one of the best detective novels ever.

Ps. The new movie was definitely not a classic. It was horrible.

title.rendered: What To Do When Machines Do Everything: How to Get Ahead in a World of AI, Algorithms, Bots, and Big Data

content.rendered:
What To Do When Machines Do Everything is a guidebook to succeeding in the next generation of the digital economy. When systems running on Artificial Intelligence can drive our cars, diagnose medical patients, and manage our finances more effectively than humans it raises profound questions on the future of work and how companies compete. Illustrated with real-world cases, data, and insight, the authors provide clear strategic guidance and actionable steps to help you and your organization move ahead in a world where exponentially developing new technologies are changing how value is created.

The first part of the book examines the once in a generation upheaval most every organization will soon face as systems of intelligence go mainstream. The authors argue that contrary to the doom and gloom that surrounds much of IT and business at the moment, we are in fact on the cusp of the biggest wave of opportunity creation since the Industrial Revolution. Next, the authors detail a clear-cut business model to help leaders take part in this coming boom; the AHEAD model outlines five strategic initiatives—Automate, Halos, Enhance, Abundance, and Discovery—that are central to competing in the next phase of global business by driving new levels of efficiency, customer intimacy and innovation.

Business leaders today have two options: be swallowed up by the ongoing technological evolution, or ride the crest of the wave to new profits and better business.

excerpt.rendered: What To Do When Machines Do Everything is a guidebook to succeeding in the next generation of the digital economy. When systems running on Artificial Intelligence can drive our cars, diagnose medical patients, and manage our finances more effectively than humans it raises profound questions on the future of work and how companies compete. Illustrated with […]

acf.author: Malcolm Frank, Paul Roehrig, Ben Pring
acf.opinion:
This was a good basic guide book for business owners and corporate managers for how to think about technological transformation caused by AI. It doesn’t go deep in technical details, but rather discusses how businesses should react and prepare for upcoming changes.

Book goes through what those changes are and what kind of jobs are going to disappear. This is a book about major tech trends and their effect. It’s a positive book since it doesn’t see development as a bad thing that takes peoples jobs away but as a natural process that has been going on for centuries. Current development is no different from industrial revolution or internet. They destroyed some old jobs too, but created new better jobs. Same is true with AI. To thrive in this new economy you simply have to keep your knowledge and skills relevant by updating them, rather than fighting windmills.
acf.who: For business leaders, managers and owners and people who want to prepare their own skills for future decades.

title.rendered: The Fast Diet: Lose Weight, Stay Healthy, Live Longer

content.rendered: Is it possible to eat well, most of the time, and get slimmer and healthier as you do it? With the Fast Diet it is. Dr Mosley’s Fast Diet has become the health phenomenon of our times. And for good reason. This radical approach to weight loss really is as simple as it sounds. You eat normally for five days a week, then for just two days you cut your calorie intake (600 for men, 500 for women).

excerpt.rendered: Is it possible to eat well, most of the time, and get slimmer and healthier as you do it? With the Fast Diet it is. Dr Mosley’s Fast Diet has become the health phenomenon of our times.

acf.author: Michael Mosley, Mimi Spencer
acf.opinion: Few years ago I tried this diet and loose 14kg during 1.5 years.  Also after that my blood values were better than ever. Now I was thinking to start it again so I finally read this book I bought back then. There also exist revised edition. Fast diet is not just about weight loss, it’s about your health and longevity. This book gives some practical advice and science behind this lifestyle.
acf.who: Anyone who want to increase their health.

content.rendered:
In a sweeping narrative that follows Franklin’s life from Boston to Philadelphia to London and Paris and back, Walter Isaacson chronicles the adventures of the runaway apprentice who became, over the course of his eighty-four-year life, America’s best writer, inventor, media baron, scientist, diplomat, and business strategist, as well as one of its most practical and ingenious political leaders. He explores the wit behind Poor Richard’s Almanac and the wisdom behind the Declaration of Independence, the new nation’s alliance with France, the treaty that ended the Revolution, and the compromises that created a near-perfect Constitution.

In this colorful and intimate narrative, Isaacson provides the full sweep of Franklin’s amazing life, showing how he helped to forge the American national identity and why he has a particular resonance in the twenty-first century.

excerpt.rendered: In this colorful and intimate narrative, Isaacson provides the full sweep of Franklin’s amazing life, showing how he helped to forge the American national identity and why he has a particular resonance in the twenty-first century.

acf.author: Walter Isaacson
acf.opinion:
This is another create biography of a great man by a worlds greatest biographer Walter Isaacson. This book is fascinating description of American History at then end of 18th century. It’s a story how 13 British colonies somehow become somewhat unified nation state. It is also a story of curious and industrial man who left his mark in history as an inventor, scientist, philosopher, writer and statesman.

Isaacson continues his series of great generalist of history. I have read his biographies of Steve Jobs and Leonardo Da Vinci.  It’s not hard to see similarities between these tree very original personalities. They were all super curious generalists who were interested in everything. They were socially skillful and already acknowledged geniuses at their own time. They all also had some faults in their personalities.
acf.who: Anyone interested in American History or society in general,

title.rendered: Business Blockchain: Promise, Practice, and Application of the Next Internet Technology

content.rendered:
The Business Blockchain charts new territory in advancing our understanding of the blockchain by unpacking its elements. William Mougayar anticipates a future that consists of thousands, if not millions of blockchains that will enable not only frictionless value exchange, but also a new flow of value, redefining roles, relationships, power and governance.

Blockchains are new technology layers that rewire the Internet and threaten to side-step older legacy constructs and centrally served businesses. At its core, a blockchain injects trust into the network, cutting off some intermediaries from serving that function and creatively disrupting how they operate. Metaphorically, blockchains are the ultimate non-stop computers. Once launched, they never go down, and offer an incredible amount of resiliency, making them dependable and attractive for running a new generation of decentralized services and software applications.

excerpt.rendered: The Business Blockchain charts new territory in advancing our understanding of the blockchain by unpacking its elements.

acf.author: William Mougayar
acf.opinion: This was a rather good book to explain how Blockchains actually work and what kind of future applications they might have. It’s not too focused on bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies but takes a broad perspective on blockchains, as it should.
acf.who: For rather technical oriented people who are interested to understand what blockchains actually do.

title.rendered: Factfulness: Ten Reasons We are Wrong About the World  – and Why Things Are Better Than You Think

content.rendered:
When asked simple questions about global trends―what percentage of the world’s population live in poverty; why the world’s population is increasing; how many girls finish school―we systematically get the answers wrong. So wrong that a chimpanzee choosing answers at random will consistently outguess teachers, journalists, Nobel laureates, and investment bankers.

In Factfulness, Professor of International Health and global TED phenomenon Hans Rosling, together with his two long-time collaborators, Anna and Ola, offers a radical new explanation of why this happens. They reveal the ten instincts that distort our perspective―from our tendency to divide the world into two camps (usually some version of us and them) to the way we consume media (where fear rules) to how we perceive progress (believing that most things are getting worse).

Our problem is that we don’t know what we don’t know, and even our guesses are informed by unconscious and predictable biases.

It turns out that the world, for all its imperfections, is in a much better state than we might think.That doesn’t mean there aren’t real concerns. But when we worry about everything all the time instead of embracing a worldview based on facts, we can lose our ability to focus on the things that threaten us most.

excerpt.rendered: Our problem is that we don’t know what we don’t know, and even our guesses are informed by unconscious and predictable biases. It turns out that the world, for all its imperfections, is in a much better state than we might think.That doesn’t mean there aren’t real concerns. But when we worry about everything all the time instead of embracing a worldview based on facts, we can lose our ability to focus on the things that threaten us most.

acf.author: Hans Rosling
acf.opinion: This is a essential book to read for anyone who want to participate in any political / philosophical discussion. This book shows some facts that we often get wrong and some typical errors we humans often do when constructing our world view.
acf.who: I think most of people should read this.

content.rendered: Today, machine learning underlies a range of applications we use every day, from product recommendations to voice recognition — as well as some we don’t yet use everyday, including driverless cars. It is the basis of the new approach in computing where we do not write programs but collect data; the idea is to learn the algorithms for the tasks automatically from data. As computing devices grow more ubiquitous, a larger part of our lives and work is recorded digitally, and as “Big Data” has gotten bigger, the theory of machine learning — the foundation of efforts to process that data into knowledge — has also advanced. In this book, machine learning expert Ethem Alpaydin offers a concise overview of the subject for the general reader, describing its evolution, explaining important learning algorithms, and presenting example applications.

excerpt.rendered: In this book, machine learning expert Ethem Alpaydin offers a concise overview of the subject for the general reader, describing its evolution, explaining important learning algorithms, and presenting example applications.

acf.author: Ethem Alpaydin
acf.opinion: This is a good basic review of Machine Learning. It’s slightly more technical than some others, but doesn’t go to practical level (code). Text in this book is not so pleasant to read, but information content is valuable.
acf.who: People who like to learn main concepts of Machine Learning, specially principles of most common learning algorithms.

title.rendered: Thinking Machines: The inside story of Artificial Intelligence and our race to build the future

content.rendered: This is a story of how what it means to be human in the face of accelerating machine intelligence. It’s about trying to make computers that are smarter than we are, and what happens when it goes wrong. About what creativity means when all knowledge is data that can be stored on microchips. Or about what happens when machines can learn from their mistakes much faster than humans can. And above all, it’s about the dazzling future around the corner, how our lives might just change forever, and whether you and I aren’t just thinking machines of a sort as well.

excerpt.rendered: This is a story of how what it means to be human in the face of accelerating machine intelligence.

acf.author: Luke Dormehl
acf.opinion: This is a good overview on basics, philosophy and history of AI research.
acf.who: Anyone interested on AI research and some core concepts.

title.rendered: The Inevitable: Understanding the 12 Technological Forces That Will Shape Our Future

content.rendered: Much of what will happen in the next thirty years is inevitable, driven by technological trends that are already in motion. In this fascinating, provocative new book, Kevin Kelly provides an optimistic road map for the future, showing how the coming changes in our lives—from virtual reality in the home to an on-demand economy to artificial intelligence embedded in everything we manufacture—can be understood as the result of a few long-term, accelerating forces. Kelly both describes these deep trends—interacting, cognifying, flowing, screening, accessing, sharing, filtering, remixing, tracking, and questioning—and demonstrates how they overlap and are codependent on one another.

excerpt.rendered: Much of what will happen in the next thirty years is inevitable, driven by technological trends that are already in motion. In this fascinating, provocative new book, Kevin Kelly provides an optimistic road map for the future.

acf.author: Kevin Kelly
acf.opinion: This is a good book about future of tech. It doesn’t try to cover the entire future of humanity, just ‘silicon valley perspective’ of technology mega trends. It focuses on ICT related technology and it gives reader a clear picture what might be coming on that front during next 30 years.
acf.who: This book is for People interested on high level tech trends.

content.rendered: Robert Langdon, Harvard professor of symbology and religious iconology, arrives at the ultramodern Guggenheim Museum Bilbao to attend a major announcement—the unveiling of a discovery that “will change the face of science forever.” The evening’s host is Edmond Kirsch, a forty-year-old billionaire and futurist whose dazzling high-tech inventions and audacious predictions have made him a renowned global figure. Kirsch, who was one of Langdon’s first students at Harvard two decades earlier, is about to reveal an astonishing breakthrough . . . one that will answer two of the fundamental questions of human existence

excerpt.rendered: Robert Langdon, Harvard professor of symbology and religious iconology, arrives at the ultramodern Guggenheim Museum Bilbao to attend a major announcement—the unveiling of a discovery that “will change the face of science forever.

acf.author: Dan Brown
acf.opinion: I have always liked Dan Brown novels and I have read them all. They certainly entertain me much more than any other novels in this genre. Like previous novels, this book is a good balance of thriller and trivia knowledge. If you have liked previous novels by same author you will like this one too. I specially liked the ending even though it was not so difficult to guess.
acf.who: People who like thrillers seasoned with cultural trivia knowledge. Also for people who are fascinated about philosophical aspects of Artificial Intelligence.

content.rendered:
Human life is a staggeringly strange thing. On the surface of a ball of rock falling around a nuclear fireball in the blackness of a vacuum the laws of nature conspired to create a naked ape that can look up at the stars and wonder where it came from.

What is a human being? Objectively, nothing of consequence. Particles of dust in an infinite arena, present for an instant in eternity. Clumps of atoms in a universe with more galaxies than people. And yet a human being is necessary for the question itself to exist, and the presence of a question in the universe – any question – is the most wonderful thing.

excerpt.rendered: Human life is a staggeringly strange thing. On the surface of a ball of rock falling around a nuclear fireball in the blackness of a vacuum the laws of nature conspired to create a naked ape that can look up at the stars and wonder where it came from.

acf.author: Brian Cox, Andrew Cohen
acf.opinion: Human universe is a very good science book which goes through history of cosmology and physics as a science. It gives lot to think. Even though it’s a book about natural sciences it’s deeply philosophical.
acf.who: For anyone interested in natural sciences and/or philosophy.

content.rendered: SPQR goes through first thousand years of Rome’s history. It focuses heavily on period between 100 BC and 100 AD.

excerpt.rendered: SPQR goes through first thousand years of Rome’s history.

acf.author: Mary Beard
acf.opinion: This is good and quite entertaining history book, but it’s not as fascinating as I was expecting. Best part of it is how it pictures life of a Roman citizens.
acf.who: People who really like Roman history.

content.rendered: A hands-on guide to building maintainable, high-performing web application user interfaces using the React JavaScript library.

excerpt.rendered: A hands-on guide to building maintainable, high-performing web application user interfaces using the React JavaScript library

acf.author: Kirupa Chinnathambi
acf.opinion: This is a really well written programming book (usually they are terrible). It puts fundamental concepts of React JS right in front of you in a way least I found easy to understand. This book is the best way to start learning from React.
acf.who: This books is for any web developer who want to start learning React JS.

content.rendered: This book is about creating a remarkable career in software development. In most cases, remarkable careers don’t come by chance. They require thought, intention, action, and a willingness to change course when you’ve made mistakes. Most of us have been stumbling around letting our careers take us where they may. It’s time to take control. This revised and updated second edition lays out a strategy for planning and creating a radically successful life in software development.

excerpt.rendered: This book is about creating a remarkable career in software development.

acf.author: Chad Fowler
acf.opinion: This was a good career guide to software developers and good career guide in general. It has some good general tips about choosing tech stacks, keeping your expertise relevant, reacting to your own mistakes, communicating and working with clients and colleagues. This book is non-technical, but it can make you a better software developer.
acf.who: This book is for Software developers

content.rendered: Locked in the silence and darkness of your skull, your brain fashions the rich narratives of your reality and your identity. Join renowned neuroscientist David Eagleman for a journey into the questions at the mysterious heart of our existence. What is reality? Who are “you”? How do you make decisions? Why does your brain need other people? How is technology poised to change what it means to be human?

excerpt.rendered: What is reality? Who are “you”? How do you make decisions? Why does your brain need other people? How is technology poised to change what it means to be human?

acf.author: David Eagleman
acf.opinion: This book was time to time quite mind blowing. You don’t think much how your brain works and why would you. But it’s actually quite fascinating and also give you a whole new perspective of what is reality vs. how you experience it. This book also has quite philosophical take on the topic.
acf.who: People interested in human biology and/or philosophy.

title.rendered: Fire and Fury: Inside The Trump White House

content.rendered: Michael Wolff tells the riveting story of how Trump launched a tenure as volatile and fiery as the man himself.In this explosive book, Wolff provides a wealth of new details about the chaos in the Oval Office.

excerpt.rendered: Michael Wolff tells the riveting story of how Trump launched a tenure as volatile and fiery as the man himself.In this explosive book, Wolff provides a wealth of new details about the chaos in the Oval Office.

acf.author: Michael Wolff
acf.opinion: I don’t know how much of this book is true, but most of it feels like a likely explanation for all that has happened. This book is definitely entertaining, though in sad kind of way.
acf.who: People who like to laugh on politics and are interested what just happened in last year and a half.

content.rendered: Forget the old concept of retirement. Whether your dream is escaping the rat race, experiencing high-end world travel, being more efficient, having a remote job or having a passive income enough to support yourself, The 4-Hour Workweek is the blueprint.

excerpt.rendered: Forget the old concept of retirement. Whether your dream is escaping the rat race, experiencing high-end world travel, being more efficient or having a passive income enough to support yourself, The 4-Hour Workweek is the blueprint.

acf.author: Timothy Ferriss
acf.opinion: This book is a lifestyle guide, but it’s also a good inspiration, even though lifestyle presented here would not b exactly the one you want. It reminds all of us that the most scarce resource we all have is time. It also reminds us that world these days is a small place where your exact location has in reality really little practical meaning. It has a interesting views on pseudo-work done in corporations and lot of practical tips how to be more efficient in every aspect of your life.
acf.who: Anyone interesting in alternative lifestyles and / or interested to have another view to your own.

content.rendered: From the birth of the universe to the creation of humankind, Stephen Fry – who fell in love with these stories as a child – retells these myths for our tragic, comic, fateful age.

excerpt.rendered: From the birth of the universe to the creation of humankind, Stephen Fry – who fell in love with these stories as a child – retells these myths for our tragic, comic, fateful age.

acf.author: Stephen Fry
acf.opinion: This was a easy way to get basic understanding of ancient Greek mythology. It’s not a complete collection, just a sample pieces from earlier stories. Unfortunately it didn’t include anything about Trojan war etc but I guess that’s going to be a sequel then.
acf.who: People interested in Greek mythology and civilizing them self about etymology of many everyday things we don’t normally give a thought.

title.rendered: Presto: How I made over 100 pounds disappear and other magical tales

content.rendered: An unconventional weight loss tale from an unconventional personality—Penn Jillette tells how he lost 100 pounds with his trademark outrageous sense of humor and biting social commentary that makes this success story anything but ordinary.

excerpt.rendered: This book is meant mostly for entertainment and maybe some inspiration. I think it has a interesting views on food culture and how what we eat is mostly habit.

acf.author: Penn Jillette
acf.opinion: This book is meant mostly for entertainment and maybe some inspiration. I would not use it as a direct guide for your diet, but I think it has a interesting views on food culture and how what we eat is mostly habit. Main reason to read this is that anything Penn Jillette writes is always going to be fun and inspiring. For myself, it inspired me to cook more vegan food.
acf.who: People who like Penn’s sense of humor and are interested about our relationship with our food.

title.rendered: How to Build a Billion Dollar App

content.rendered: In How to Build a Billion Dollar App, serial tech entrepreneur George Berkowski gives you exclusive access to the secrets behind the success of the select group of purely mobile app based companies that have achieved billion-dollar success, including two Finnish gaming companies SuperCell and Rovio.

excerpt.rendered: Book about mobile app business

acf.author: George Berkowski
acf.opinion: This is a good business that focus on the world of mobile apps. It is useful, even though your goal would not be on billion dollars, but more modest numbers. If you are planning to have a company where your product is a mobile app, this is probably a good read.
acf.who: Anyone interested in mobile app business.

content.rendered: Based on thousands of pages from Leonardo’s astonishing notebooks and new discoveries about his life and work, Walter Isaacson weaves a narrative that connects his art to his science. He shows how Leonardo’s genius was based on skills we can improve in ourselves, such as passionate curiosity, careful observation, and an imagination so playful that it flirted with fantasy.

excerpt.rendered: Based on thousands of pages from Leonardo’s astonishing notebooks and new discoveries about his life and work, Walter Isaacson weaves a narrative that connects his art to his science. He shows how Leonardo’s genius was based on skills we can improve in ourselves, such as passionate curiosity, careful observation, and an imagination so playful that it flirted with fantasy.

acf.author: Walter Isaacson
acf.opinion: This is a excellent biography of a genius man by a great writer. I have read one other biography by Isaacson (Steve Jobs). That one was really good and this one is maybe even better. It’s inspirational, fascinating and honest. It gives reader a clear picture of what kind of man Leonardo was, what were his accomplishments and setbacks. It also pictures the zeitgeist of Renaissance era Italy.
acf.who: Anyone interested in zeitgeist of Renaissance era, art history or history of natural sciences and naturally anyone who is interested what kind of person was Leonardo Da Vinci.

title.rendered: Homo Deus: A Brief History of Tomorrow

content.rendered: Harari’s previous book (Sapiens) was about history of our species. This one is all about where we are going next. Is our species going to exists as a Homo Sapiens in the future or a upgraded Homo Deus. Book is a mixture of natural sciences, history and philosophy. Harari gives both utopian and dystopian theories what will happen to old myths keeping our society together and what kind of society we might found ourself in near future.

excerpt.rendered: Harari’s previous book (Sapiens) was about history of our species. This one is all about where we are going next.

acf.author: Yuval Noah Harari
acf.opinion: Like previous book this one is quite provocative and philosophically deep. It gives you some insides and notes where we are going, but it also force you to think.
acf.who: People who are interested in philosophy, theories of future society and effects of technological development. Also it’s good if reader don’t mind to be provoked. I recommend reading Harari’s first book ‘Sapiens‘ first.

title.rendered: Zero To One: Notes on startups of how to build the future

content.rendered: The great secret of our time is that there are still uncharted frontiers to explore and new inventions to create. In Zero to One, legendary entrepreneur and investor Peter Thiel shows how we can find singular ways to create those new things.

excerpt.rendered: The great secret of our time is that there are still uncharted frontiers to explore and new inventions to create. In Zero to One, legendary entrepreneur and investor Peter Thiel shows how we can find singular ways to create those new things.

acf.author: Peter Thiel with Blake Masters
acf.opinion: This is a great business book. It has some controversial and bold viewpoints with good arguments. Also writer has some competence for his claims since he co-founded and sold PayPal and was first outside investor of Facebook.
acf.who: Though focus group seem to be entrepreneurs this is good for anyone who is interested in business.

title.rendered: Start With Why: How Great Leaders Inspire Everyone To Take Action

content.rendered: Why are some people and organizations more innovative, more influential, and more profitable than others? Why do some command greater loyalty from customers and employees alike? Even among the successful, why are so few able to repeat their success over and over? This book try to answer these questions with simple idea: those companies start with a question: ‘why we exist?’

excerpt.rendered: Why are some people and organizations more innovative, more influential, and more profitable than others? Why do some command greater loyalty from customers and employees alike?

acf.author: Simon Sinek
acf.opinion: This was a good business book and I think it is useful for most leaders and entrepreneurs to remember why company exist in a first place and use that as a guideline when making decisions.
acf.who: Corporate leaders, entrepreneurs, communications- and marketing people.

title.rendered: Prisoners of Geography: Ten maps that tell you everything about global politics

content.rendered: This is a book about geopolitics of the World and emphasize the often forgotten meaning of geography. This book gives geographical reasons why world leaders do what they do, why certain countries are destined to be what they are and why certain things happen or won’t happen. Geography is not the only factor in world politics, but it’s usually most overlooked.

excerpt.rendered: This is a book about geopolitics of the World and emphasize the often forgotten meaning of geography. This book gives geographical reasons why world leaders do what they do, why certain countries are destined to be what they are and why certain things happen or won’t happen. Geography is not the only factor in world […]

acf.author: Tim Marshall
acf.opinion: This book is a real eye opener. After you read it you will never watch the news same again. Read it, it’s awesome.
acf.who: Must read for anyone interested in World politics.

title.rendered: Silk Roads: A New History Of The World

content.rendered: Silk Roads is a book of world history that promises to take non-euro-centric view on world history. Specially it emphasize importance of Middle East and Central Asia.

excerpt.rendered: Silk Roads is a book of world history that promises to take non-euro-centric view on world history. Specially it emphasize importance of Middle East and Central Asia.

acf.author: Peter Frankopan
acf.opinion: I think this book doesn’t quite deliver what it promises. It’s a good history book, but it does have quite Europe-centric view and it basically skips for example Chinese history, which I would expect to hear something based on books name. Focus is on history of European colonialism, Middle East and Central Asia.
acf.who: People interested in middle eastern and Central Asian history.

title.rendered: Astrophysics for People in a Hurry

content.rendered: Neil deGrasse Tyson’s latest book is a popular science book that aims to give basics of astrophysics for us busy people who don’t have much time to study structure of universe.

excerpt.rendered: Neil deGrasse Tyson’s latest book is a popular science book that aims to give basics of astrophysics for us busy people who don’t have much time to study structure of universe.

acf.author: Neil deGrasse Tyson
acf.opinion: This was a good book, but includes mostly same stuff as other popular science books about astrophysics. So if you have read for example A Brief History of Time by Stephen Hawking, there is a lot of familiar in this book. But if you have not read anything similar, I suggest you read this one, since it might spark your interest.
acf.who: For anyone who has not read any other popular science book about same topic and for those who have but can’t get enough 🙂

content.rendered: The ABC Murders is a Hercule Poirot Crime novel. In this adventure Poirot meets a serial killer who sends Poirot letters signed by A.B.C. In each is given the date and location of the next murder. This Poirot novel features also classic sidekick Arthur Hastings.

excerpt.rendered: The ABC Murders is a Hercule Poirot Crime novel. In this adventure Poirot meets a serial killer who sends Poirot letters signed by A.B.C.

acf.author: Agatha Christie
acf.opinion: This is excellent Poirot Novel. Ending will surprice you, even though you know something surprising is going to happen.
acf.who: Anyone who like classic detective novels.

title.rendered: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind

content.rendered:
Sapiens is a story of our species Homo Sapiens. Approach is a mixture of philosophy, history and natural sciences. It start from extinction of other human species like Homo Neanderthal and Homo Erectus. It goes through how this one species of big monkeys start building cities and empires. Book ends with speculations what’s going to happen to homo sapiens in future.

Books asks and answers questions like: why we believe in religions, governments, money or laws and how these human made “myths” have help us to work in a big groups like nations and empires?

excerpt.rendered: Sapiens is a story of our species Homo Sapiens. Approach is a mixture of philosophy, history and natural sciences.

acf.author: Yuaval Noah Harari
acf.opinion: This book is first of all one of the best none-fiction books I have read for a long time. It’s a fascinating story of humankind and interesting analysis of society. It has some clever philosophical points, though author is sometimes bit cynical and repeats his points more than it is necessary. It is by design provocative, but it does it smart way.
acf.who: I would definitely recommend this book to anyone interested on World history or other social sciences.

title.rendered: Harry Potter And The Cursed Child

content.rendered: This is not a novel. It’s a script book for the theatre play of the same name written by J. K. Rowling, John Tiffany, and Jack Thorne. Events happen after the last actual Harry Potter novel and feature mostly Harry Potters son Albus Severus Potter.

excerpt.rendered: This is not a novel. It’s a script book for the theatre play of the same name written by J. K. Rowling, John Tiffany, and Jack Thorne. Events happen after the last actual Harry Potter novel and feature mostly Harry Potters son Albus Severus Potter.

acf.author: J.K. Rowling, John Tiffany and Jack Thorne.
acf.opinion: Since this is a script not a novel, it’s not so enjoyable to read. You won’t get same satisfaction as you get reading original novel series. Also the plot is bit silly and feels more like fan fiction, though it might work better on stage. Ending of the book is quite fun so that saves a lot and it’s still Harry Potter book so I’m ready to forgive a lot.
acf.who: I would recommend this book for only die hard Harry Potter fans, like myself.

content.rendered: This book is the final Hercule Poirot novel that reunites Poirot and Hastings for the one last case. Novel also return the characters to the setting of their first case: The Mysterious Affair at Styles.

excerpt.rendered: This book is the final Hercule Poirot novel that reunites Poirot and Hastings for the one last case. Novel also return the characters to the setting of their first case: The Mysterious Affair at Styles.

acf.author: Agatha Christie
acf.opinion: This is not the best of Agatha Christies Poirot books, but it has one of the most surprising and most shocking ending. Besides anything Agatha Christie has wrote is least really good.
acf.who: Anyone who like classic detective novels.

content.rendered: Catalyst is a prequel novel for Rogue One Star Wars story movie. It explains what happened to characters before the movie and how they end up way they are.

excerpt.rendered: Catalyst is a prequel novel for Rogue One Star Wars story movie. It explains what happened to characters before the movie and how they end up way they are.

acf.author: James Luceno
acf.opinion: Catalyst was quite ok novel that gives a lot of background information about characters in the movie, but way it’s wrote feels bit stretched. There is just not enough story to justify book this long.
acf.who: This is a book for big Star Wars fans.
